wiki_catalogs.name: Introduction
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the framework's core purpose and architectural vision. Explain that this is a lightweight, modular PHP MVC framework built with native PHP and no external dependencies, designed for clean separation of concerns and extensibility via dependency injection and service providers. Describe the high-level components: MVC system, DI container, database abstraction, event management, and modular structure. Illustrate the request lifecycle from public/index.php through bootstrap.php to Application::handle(), routing, dispatching, and response. Highlight key design decisions such as manual autoloading, service provider pattern, and configuration-driven modules. Include a simple diagram showing component relationships and data flow. Provide context for both beginners (MVC, DI concepts) and experienced developers (patterns used, extension points). Reference real code examples from config.php for module routing, bootstrap.php for service registration, and index.php for entry point.

wiki_catalogs.name: Application Lifecycle
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Application component as the central orchestrator of the framework's request lifecycle. Explain its role in initializing the DI container, registering service providers, and coordinating the flow from request reception to response dispatch. Detail the sequence: bootstrapping via bootstrap.php, route matching through Router, controller dispatching via Dispatcher, and final response rendering. Document public methods such as handle(), setRouter(), and setDispatcher(), including their parameters and integration points. Illustrate with a sequence diagram showing interaction between Application, Router, Dispatcher, and Controller. Highlight lifecycle events triggered by the Events Manager during execution. Address common configuration patterns, error handling during bootstrap, and performance implications of service initialization order. Provide a real-world example from usign-app.php to demonstrate setup and execution flow.

wiki_catalogs.name: Action Methods
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for controller action methods. Explain how the Dispatcher locates and invokes action methods using the 'Action' suffix convention (e.g., indexAction). Document the dispatch flow: route resolution, controller instantiation via DI, method existence check, and return value handling. Describe how return values are interpreted—Response objects passed directly, arrays converted to JSON, and strings treated as HTML content. Use Dashboard.php's indexAction as an example to show data preparation and view rendering. Cover proper action naming, parameter access via Dispatcher::getParam(), and HTTP method handling using Controller::isPost() and Controller::getPost(). Include error handling for missing actions and invalid responses.

wiki_catalogs.name: Request Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Request object implementation. Explain how the Request class encapsulates HTTP input by aggregating $_GET, $_POST, $_SERVER, and JSON payloads through its constructor and helper methods. Document key methods such as get(), post(), input(), all(), and has() for retrieving user input with fallbacks and defaults. Describe advanced features including method spoofing via _method parameter, URI and IP extraction, header parsing with case normalization, and AJAX detection via X-Requested-With header. Illustrate how the Request object integrates with the MVC flow by being injected into controller actions, as shown in UserController examples. Provide code examples demonstrating input validation, conditional logic based on request method, and secure access to user data. Address common issues like missing input handling, JSON parsing failures, and server variable availability in different environments. Include performance considerations for large payloads and security best practices such as input sanitization and CSRF mitigation strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Model System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Model system. Explain how Model.php serves as the base class for all database entities, providing built-in CRUD operations, automatic table mapping, and attribute handling. Document the relationship system with HasOne, BelongsTo, HasMany, and BelongsToMany classes, showing how they enable eager and lazy loading of related data. Include examples from Users.php and Tasks.php models demonstrating real-world usage. Describe the lifecycle methods like beforeSave and afterFetch, and integration with the DI container for service access. Address common issues such as N+1 query problems, relationship configuration errors, and performance implications of recursive loading. Provide optimization strategies including selective field loading and relationship caching.

wiki_catalogs.name: Session Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Session management system. Explain the implementation of the Session class, including its initialization via SessionServiceProvider and configuration options defined in config.php such as session lifetime, cookie parameters, and storage settings. Document methods for starting, writing, and destroying sessions. Describe the flash message mechanism for transient user feedback and how it is cleared after display. Provide code examples from the framework showing how controllers set and retrieve session data. Explain integration with the DI container and how session services are injected into components. Address common issues like session persistence across requests, session regeneration for security, and handling session timeouts. Include best practices for preventing session fixation and securing session cookies using secure, HttpOnly, and SameSite flags.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Usage Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for database usage examples. Explain how the example demonstrates model instantiation, CRUD operations, and query builder usage. Walk through the interaction between the Model class and Database service, showing how queries are constructed and executed. Include code snippets from database-usage.php illustrating SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE operations. Explain how relationships (BelongsTo, HasMany) can be extended from this example. Document configuration requirements for connecting to the database and troubleshooting common issues like connection failures or query errors. Provide guidance on securing database interactions and optimizing performance with indexing and eager loading.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for getting started with the framework. Provide step-by-step instructions for setting up the project: file placement under web root, database configuration in config.php, and running migrations via public/migrate.php. Explain the directory structure with focus on app/, public/, examples/, and migrations/. Walk through the first request flow starting from public/index.php, loading bootstrap.php, initializing the DI container, and handling the request through Application. Include a minimal 'Hello World' example by creating a custom controller and route in config.php. Demonstrate how to access services like request, response, and view from a controller. Use examples/usign-app.php to show basic application usage patterns. Address common setup issues such as path configuration, URL rewriting, and database connection errors. Keep explanations beginner-friendly while providing enough technical detail for immediate implementation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dependency Injection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Dependency Injection system. Thoroughly explain the Container class as a service locator and object resolver, supporting singleton and transient bindings. Describe how ContainerBuilder facilitates service registration and provider loading from config.php. Explain the Injectable trait enabling automatic dependency resolution in controllers and components. Document the ServiceProvider interface and its implementation in modules like ViewServiceProvider.php for decoupled service registration. Include code examples showing service definition, parameterized instantiation, and interface-to-concrete binding. Illustrate the resolution process when Dispatcher instantiates controllers with injected Request, Response, or Database services. Address common issues such as circular dependencies, missing service exceptions, and debugging unresolved bindings. Discuss performance benefits of lazy loading versus eager initialization and best practices for organizing service providers in modular applications.

wiki_catalogs.name: Lifecycle Callbacks
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for controller lifecycle callbacks: initialize() and afterExecute(). Explain their execution timing—initialize() before action dispatch, afterExecute() after action completion. Describe use cases such as authentication checks, permission validation, and resource initialization in initialize(), and logging, cleanup, or response modification in afterExecute(). Document how the Dispatcher checks for these methods and calls them conditionally. Provide examples of implementing initialize() to restrict controller access and afterExecute() for audit logging. Address common issues like method signature errors, unintended side effects, and ensuring parent method calls when extending base controllers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Response Generation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Response object implementation. Explain how the Response class manages HTTP output through content, status codes, and headers, with built-in constants for common HTTP statuses. Document instance methods like setContent(), setStatusCode(), and setHeader() for mutable response construction, and demonstrate their usage in controller workflows. Detail static factory methods including json(), redirect(), and error() for common response patterns, showing how they streamline API and web application development. Describe the send() method's role in emitting headers and content while preventing duplicate output via the sent flag. Illustrate integration with the MVC system through controller return values and middleware, using examples from UserController and CorsMiddleware. Cover advanced use cases such as multiple Set-Cookie headers and custom header management. Address common issues like headers already sent errors, improper JSON encoding, and redirect loops. Include performance tips on response buffering and security considerations for header injection and secure redirects.

wiki_catalogs.name: Query Builder
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Query Builder. Thoroughly explain the fluent interface of QueryBuilder.php for constructing dynamic SQL queries using methods like select, where, join, orderBy, and limit. Document how it integrates with Database.php for secure query execution using PDO prepared statements. Include practical examples from database-usage.php showing SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE operations. Explain advanced features such as subqueries, raw expressions, and transaction support. Describe how the builder prevents SQL injection and handles different SQL data types. Address common issues like malformed queries, parameter binding errors, and performance bottlenecks with complex joins. Provide best practices for query optimization and debugging techniques.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cookie Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Cookie handling system. Explain the implementation of the Cookie class with secure defaults including HttpOnly, SameSite, and secure flags configured via config.php. Describe how the CookieServiceProvider registers the service in the DI container for dependency injection. Document public methods for setting, retrieving, and deleting cookies with support for expiration, path, domain, and encryption. Provide practical examples from the codebase demonstrating cookie usage in controllers and middleware-like logic. Explain how cookies integrate with session management and authentication flows. Address browser compatibility concerns with SameSite policies (Lax vs Strict), secure flag requirements over HTTPS, and strategies for preventing XSS-based cookie theft. Include troubleshooting tips for common issues such as cookies not being set due to response already sent or domain mismatches.

wiki_catalogs.name: DateTime Helper Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for DateTime helper usage. Explain how DateTimeHelper.php is utilized to format, parse, and manipulate date/time values in the application. Provide code examples from datatime-usage.php demonstrating common operations such as timestamp formatting, relative time (e.g., '2 hours ago'), and timezone handling. Show integration points with models and views where date formatting is required. Document best practices for consistent date handling across the application and address potential pitfalls like timezone mismatches or daylight saving time issues. Include performance tips for caching formatted dates when rendering large datasets.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the framework's core components. Describe the MVC architecture with Application as the central coordinator, Router for route matching, Dispatcher for controller instantiation, and View for rendering. Explain the Dependency Injection container's role in managing service lifecycle and resolving dependencies via injection in controllers and other components. Detail the Event system's implementation using the Observer pattern, with Manager handling event registration and propagation across key lifecycle hooks like 'application:beforeHandle' and 'core:beforeDispatch'. Illustrate how these components interact through the DI container, using bootstrap.php as the service registration blueprint. Include sequence diagrams for request handling and service resolution. Discuss architectural trade-offs: performance benefits of lightweight design vs. missing features from full-stack frameworks. Address scalability considerations and thread safety implications of persistent database connections.

wiki_catalogs.name: Events System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the event-driven architecture using the Observer pattern. Detail the Manager class as the central hub for event subscription, dispatching, and propagation. Explain Event class structure, including event name, target, and parameters, and how StoppableEventInterface allows short-circuiting of event chains. Document methods like attach(), detach(), and fire() with usage examples from core lifecycle hooks such as 'application:beforeHandle' and 'core:beforeDispatch'. Show how components implement EventAware to become event-capable. Provide practical examples from events-usage.php demonstrating custom event creation and listener registration. Illustrate data flow when an event is fired and handled across multiple listeners. Address common pitfalls like memory leaks from unremoved listeners, performance impact of synchronous event processing, and strategies for error handling within listeners. Recommend patterns for using events in modular applications to maintain loose coupling between components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Accessing Services via DI
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content on how controllers access framework services through the Dependency Injection container. Explain the Injectable trait that enables getDI() and direct service access. Document built-in service shortcuts: getRequest(), getView(), and session access via flashSuccess()/flashError(). Show how to retrieve any registered service (e.g., database, events) using $this->getDI()->get('service_name'). Use Dashboard.php to illustrate view data passing and User.php for form handling with request data. Cover best practices for service usage, avoiding tight coupling, and testing considerations. Address common issues like service not found exceptions and improper DI container usage.

wiki_catalogs.name: File Upload Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for file upload handling using UploadedFile and Request integration. Explain how the Request class normalizes $_FILES into UploadedFile objects during construction, supporting both single and multiple file uploads through the normalizeFiles() method. Document the UploadedFile class interface including moveTo(), isValid(), getClientOriginalName(), getClientMimeType(), and getSize() methods, emphasizing safe file handling practices. Demonstrate usage patterns from the examples where file uploads are accessed via $request->file('key') and moved to secure locations. Illustrate validation workflows using isValid() to check upload errors before processing. Cover advanced scenarios such as handling array-style file inputs and validating file types or sizes. Address common issues like upload size limits, temporary file cleanup, and race conditions during moveTo(). Include security considerations such as avoiding path traversal, validating MIME types, and storing files outside web root. Provide performance guidance for large file handling and server configuration tuning.

wiki_catalogs.name: Migrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Migrations system. Explain how Migration.php defines schema changes using versioned classes, and how Migrator.php applies them sequentially through MigrationRepository.php. Document the Blueprint.php DSL for declarative table creation and modification, including ColumnDefinition.php for field specifications. Use actual migration files to illustrate creating users, posts, and tasks tables with proper indexes and constraints. Describe the migration lifecycle: up(), down(), status checking, and rollback procedures. Explain how public/migrate.php serves as the CLI entry point. Address common issues such as migration conflicts, failed rollbacks, and schema drift. Provide strategies for zero-downtime migrations, data seeding, and team collaboration on schema changes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Events System Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for event system usage. Explain how the example demonstrates event registration, triggering, and listener execution using the Events\Manager class. Walk through the process of attaching listeners to events like 'application:beforeHandle' or custom events. Use code from events-usage.php to show how closures and callable objects can be used as listeners. Illustrate event propagation and how StoppableEventInterface controls further processing. Discuss real-world use cases such as logging, authentication checks, or response modification. Address common issues like event order dependency and memory leaks from unremoved listeners.

wiki_catalogs.name: Routing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the routing system. Explain how routes are defined in config.php under 'modules' => 'routes', with URL patterns mapped to controller and action. Describe the Router class's implementation using regex pattern matching, parameter extraction (e.g., /admin/user-edit/{id}), and HTTP method constraints. Demonstrate route definition for common scenarios: static routes, parameterized routes, and RESTful patterns. Show how the Router integrates with the Dispatcher to instantiate controllers. Provide examples from the Admin module routes in config.php. Address common issues like route ordering, parameter validation, and 404 handling. Include performance tips such as minimizing complex regex patterns and caching route collections. Document the internal mechanics of route compilation and matching algorithm.

wiki_catalogs.name: Response Handling and Redirection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content on response generation and redirection in controllers. Explain the framework's response handling: returning strings for HTML, arrays for JSON, or Response objects for full control. Document the Controller's helper methods: redirect() for HTTP redirects and render() for view rendering. Show how redirect() constructs URLs and sends immediate responses using Response::redirect()->send(). Illustrate render() usage with template paths and data binding from Dashboard.php. Cover Response class capabilities: status codes, headers, and JSON responses. Address best practices for terminating responses, avoiding output before redirects, and handling AJAX responses. Include troubleshooting for redirect loops and missing output.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Database Configuration. Explain how database connection settings are defined in the 'db' section of config.php, including host, database, username, password, and driver options. Document how bootstrap.php initializes the Database service in the DI container using these settings. Describe connection pooling, persistent connections, and charset configuration options. Show how multiple database connections can be configured and accessed via named services. Address security considerations like credential storage, SSL enforcement, and connection timeout settings. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common connection issues such as refused connections, authentication failures, and network timeouts. Include performance tuning tips for connection limits and query caching.

wiki_catalogs.name: Forms Builder Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for form builder usage. Explain how the example demonstrates the creation of HTML forms using the Forms\Builder and Form classes. Walk through generating input fields, setting attributes, handling validation states, and rendering complete forms. Use code from forms-usage.php to show dynamic form construction and integration with controller actions. Illustrate how forms interact with models for data binding and error display. Provide guidance on extending the form system with custom field types and client-side validation. Address security considerations like CSRF protection and XSS prevention when rendering user input.

wiki_catalogs.name: Controllers
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for controller implementation and usage. Explain the base Controller class's responsibilities: accessing DI services, handling requests, returning responses, and managing view data. Describe the Dispatcher's role in instantiating controllers via DI and invoking action methods. Document lifecycle methods like initialize() and afterExecute() for pre/post-processing. Show examples from Dashboard.php and User.php controllers demonstrating action methods, form handling, and redirection. Explain how to access Request, Response, Session, and View services through the DI container. Cover best practices for action naming, parameter handling, and error responses. Address common issues like method not found errors, access to DI services, and proper response termination.

wiki_catalogs.name: HTTP Request and Response Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for HTTP request and response handling. Explain how the example demonstrates accessing request data (GET, POST, headers, files) via the Http\Request object and constructing responses using Http\Response. Use code from http-req-res.php to show retrieving input parameters, uploading files with UploadedFile, setting response headers, and sending JSON or redirect responses. Illustrate the lifecycle of a request from dispatch to response output. Discuss best practices for content negotiation, status code usage, and handling large payloads. Address common issues like missing input sanitization or incorrect header ordering.

wiki_catalogs.name: Views & Templates
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the view rendering system. Explain how the View component processes PHTML templates, supports layouts, and handles data passing from controllers. Describe layout usage with examples from default.phtml and admin.phtml, showing how content is injected via $this->getContent(). Document partials and view components using examples like partials_alert.phtml. Show how to pass data from controllers to views and access DI services within templates. Illustrate the directory structure under app/views/module/ and layout resolution mechanism. Provide examples of template inheritance and component registration via View::registerComponent(). Address common issues like variable scope, escaping output, and layout nesting problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Migrations Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for database migration usage. Explain how the example demonstrates defining schema changes using the Migration and Blueprint classes. Walk through creating tables, modifying columns, adding indexes, and managing relationships via migration files. Use code from migrations.php to illustrate up() and down() methods for reversible changes. Show how Migrator.php applies migrations and tracks them in the migration repository. Provide guidance on structuring migration workflows in team environments and handling failed migrations. Address common issues like migration conflicts, irreversible operations, and data loss risks during rollbacks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the database layer. Detail the Database class as a PDO wrapper with query execution and connection management. Explain the Model system with base Model.php class providing CRUD operations and relationship handling via Relation.php, HasOne.php, BelongsTo.php, etc. Document the QueryBuilder's fluent interface for constructing SQL queries. Describe the migration system with Migration class for versioning and Migrator for applying schema changes, using examples from migration files. Include schema diagrams for Users, Tasks, and Posts tables from migration SQL. Explain configuration in config.php under 'db' section. Cover data access patterns, transaction handling, and performance considerations like indexing and query optimization. Address common issues such as connection timeouts, migration conflicts, and relationship loading performance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Application Initialization Example
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for application initialization and usage. Explain how the example demonstrates bootstrapping the framework using the Application class, setting up routing, and handling requests programmatically. Use code from usign-app.php to show manual instantiation of the application, configuration of modules, and dispatching requests outside the standard public/index.php flow. Illustrate integration with custom entry points or CLI tools. Discuss advanced use cases like microservices or embedded applications using this pattern. Address common configuration mistakes and lifecycle management issues when bypassing the default bootstrap process.

wiki_catalogs.name: HTTP Services
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for HTTP request and response handling. Explain the Request object's capabilities: retrieving input data, headers, server parameters, and uploaded files via UploadedFile. Describe the Response object's methods for sending JSON, HTML, redirects, and custom headers. Show usage examples from http-req-res.php demonstrating request data access and response generation. Document file upload handling with validation and storage patterns. Explain how Request and Response integrate with the MVC flow through the Application and Controller components. Cover security considerations like input sanitization, CSRF protection (if applicable), and secure header management. Address common issues such as large file uploads, JSON parsing errors, and response buffering problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cookie Management in Controllers
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for cookie handling within controllers. Explain how the example demonstrates setting, reading, and deleting cookies using the Cookie service injected into controllers. Use code from using-cookie-controller.php to show interaction with the CookieInterface and CookieServiceProvider. Illustrate secure cookie practices including HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags. Provide real-world use cases such as user preferences, tracking tokens, or session fallbacks. Address browser compatibility, size limits, and privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR) when implementing cookie-based features.

wiki_catalogs.name: Session & Cookies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for session and cookie management. Explain the Session class implementation with configuration options from config.php (lifetime, cookie settings). Describe flash messages pattern for temporary session data. Detail the Cookie class's secure cookie handling with SameSite, HttpOnly, and secure flags configured in config.php. Show how service providers (SessionServiceProvider, CookieServiceProvider) register these services in the DI container. Provide examples of setting, retrieving, and deleting session data and cookies. Document security best practices: secure flag usage, session regeneration, and protection against session fixation. Address common issues like session persistence across requests, cookie domain settings, and browser compatibility with SameSite policies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dependency Injection Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for dependency injection usage. Explain how the example demonstrates service registration, resolution, and injection via the Di\Container. Use code from using-di.php to illustrate defining services with closures, factory methods, and shared instances. Show how injectable classes retrieve dependencies through the container. Discuss advanced patterns like method injection, conditional binding, and service decorators. Provide best practices for organizing service providers and avoiding circular dependencies. Address performance implications of service instantiation and debugging container resolution issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Forms
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the form building system. Explain the Form and Builder classes' roles in generating HTML forms programmatically. Show how to create forms with various input types, labels, and validation attributes. Use UserForm.php and TaskForm.php as examples of form class implementations. Demonstrate usage patterns from forms-usage.php including field addition, value binding, and rendering. Document integration with views and controller submission handling. Address common issues like CSRF protection (if implemented), error display, and dynamic form generation. Provide best practices for accessibility, validation, and styling integration with CSS frameworks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Providers
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for service providers as extension points. Explain the ServiceProvider interface and its register() method for service registration in the DI container. Describe how providers like ViewServiceProvider, SessionServiceProvider, and CookieServiceProvider encapsulate service configuration. Show how to create custom service providers for application-specific services. Use bootstrap.php as an example of provider registration via $di->register(). Document best practices for service lifecycle management (shared vs. transient), dependency ordering, and error handling during registration. Address common issues like circular dependencies, service resolution failures, and provider loading order. Include examples of registering third-party libraries or custom business services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Events
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the event system. Explain the Event and Manager classes' implementation of the Observer pattern. Describe how to attach listeners to events like 'application:beforeHandle' and 'core:beforeDispatch' using Manager::attach(). Show how to trigger custom events with Event::fire() and pass parameters to listeners. Use examples/events-usage.php to demonstrate event registration and handling. Document the StoppableEventInterface for cancelable events. Explain use cases: logging, authentication checks, response modification. Address common issues like event listener memory leaks, execution order, and performance impact of synchronous event processing. Provide patterns for error handling within event listeners.

wiki_catalogs.name: Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content showcasing practical usage examples. Organize examples by functionality: database-usage.php for model and query operations, di-usage.php for dependency injection patterns, http-req-res.php for request/response handling, and migrations.php for database schema management. For each example, provide context, code walkthrough, and explanation of key concepts demonstrated. Show how to adapt these examples to real-world scenarios. Include a complete small application example that integrates multiple components: routing, controller, model, view, and form handling. Document setup requirements for running examples and expected outputs. Address common adaptation issues when applying example patterns to production code.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis

## 1. Project Introduction

This project is a custom-built PHP MVC framework designed for web application development. It provides a structured architecture with dependency injection, routing, database management, and HTTP handling capabilities. The core purpose is to offer a lightweight, modular foundation for building web applications with clean separation of concerns.

The primary goals include:
- Implementing a robust MVC pattern
- Providing database abstraction and migration tools
- Supporting dependency injection for service management
- Offering HTTP request/response handling
- Enabling modular application structure

The target audience consists of PHP developers who need a flexible framework for building web applications without the overhead of larger frameworks.

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The project follows a modular MVC architecture with several core components:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client] --> B[Public/index.php]
    B --> C[Bootstrap]
    C --> D[Application]
    D --> E[Router]
    E --> F[Dispatcher]
    F --> G[Controller]
    G --> H[Model]
    G --> I[View]
    H --> J[Database]
    I --> K[Views]
```

### Design Patterns

The system implements several key design patterns:
- **MVC Pattern**: Clear separation between Model, View, and Controller
- **Dependency Injection**: Container-based service management
- **Service Provider Pattern**: Modular service registration
- **Singleton Pattern**: For shared services via DI container
- **Observer Pattern**: Event management system

### System Relationships

```mermaid
graph TD
    Application --> Router
    Application --> Dispatcher
    Application --> EventsManager
    Dispatcher --> Controller
    Controller --> Model
    Controller --> View
    Model --> Database
    View --> Layouts
    DI[DI Container] --> Services
    Services --> Session
    Services --> Cookie
    Services --> Database
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- **public/index.php**: Primary entry point for web requests
- **app/bootstrap.php**: Application initialization and service registration
- **public/migrate.php**: Database migration execution point

### Core Modules
- **Core/Mvc/Application.php**: Main application class handling request lifecycle
- **Core/Mvc/Router.php**: URL routing and pattern matching
- **Core/Mvc/Dispatcher.php**: Controller and action dispatching
- **Core/Di/Container.php**: Dependency injection container
- **Core/Database/Database.php**: Database connection and query execution

### Configuration Approach
- **app/config.php**: Central configuration file with module, database, and service settings
- Environment-specific configuration through array structure
- Module-based routing configuration

### External Dependencies
The project appears to be self-contained with no external package dependencies, relying on PHP's built-in functions and features.

### Integration Points
- **Database**: MySQL integration through native PHP drivers
- **Session Management**: PHP session handling with custom service provider
- **Cookie Handling**: Custom cookie management implementation
- **File Uploads**: HTTP file upload processing

```mermaid
graph LR
    Client --> WebServer
    WebServer --> index.php
    index.php --> Bootstrap
    Bootstrap --> DIContainer
    DIContainer --> Application
    Application --> Router
    Router --> Dispatcher
    Dispatcher --> Controllers
    Controllers --> Models
    Controllers --> Views
    Models --> Database
    Views --> Templates
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The framework provides comprehensive web application features including:
- RESTful routing system
- Request/response handling
- Database abstraction and ORM-like models
- Migration system for database schema management
- Dependency injection and service container
- Event management system
- Form handling capabilities

### Implementation Highlights
- **Modular Architecture**: Support for multiple modules with independent routing
- **Flexible Routing**: Pattern-based routing with parameter extraction
- **Database Migrations**: Version-controlled schema changes
- **HTTP Abstraction**: Comprehensive request and response objects
- **Service Providers**: Extensible service registration system

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Initialization
    Initialization --> Routing
    Routing --> Dispatching
    Dispatching --> ControllerExecution
    ControllerExecution --> ResponsePreparation
    ResponsePreparation --> Output
    Output --> [*]
    
    ControllerExecution --> DatabaseAccess: If needed
    ControllerExecution --> ViewRendering: If HTML response
    DatabaseAccess --> ControllerExecution
    ViewRendering --> ControllerExecution
```

Sources:
- [bootstrap.php](c:\xampp\htdocs\new\app\bootstrap.php)
- [index.php](c:\xampp\htdocs\new\public\index.php)
- [config.php](c:\xampp\htdocs\new\app\config.php)
- [Application.php](c:\xampp\htdocs\new\app\Core\Mvc\Application.php)
- [Router.php](c:\xampp\htdocs\new\app\Core\Mvc\Router.php)
- [Dispatcher.php](c:\xampp\htdocs\new\app\Core\Mvc\Dispatcher.php)
- [Request.php](c:\xampp\htdocs\new\app\Core\Http\Request.php)
- [Response.php](c:\xampp\htdocs\new\app\Core\Http\Response.php)
</blog>

wiki_repo.name: new
wiki_repo.optimized_catalog:
".
